key_points: A 12-person jury acquitted Kyle Rittenhouse of all five charges after he fatally shot two people and wounded a third during protests in Kenosha, Wisconsin.
Rittenhouse was charged with five felonies, including first-degree intentional homicide and first-degree reckless homicide.
The trial lasted two weeks, featuring testimony from over 30 witnesses and intense scrutiny of the divided nation.
Legal experts indicated Rittenhouse's testimony, where he claimed he acted in self-defense, played a crucial role in his acquittal.
Defense attorney Mark Richards emphasized the decision to have Rittenhouse testify was pivotal, influenced by mock jury results.
The trial focused on whether Rittenhouse was a vigilant victim or a provocateur. The jury concluded he acted in self-defense.
Wisconsin law requires the prosecution to disprove self-defense beyond a reasonable doubt, a burden the prosecution could not meet.
Missteps by the prosecution, including attempting to brand Rittenhouse as an active shooter, were criticized by legal experts.
The judge twice admonished Prosecutor Thomas Binger for inappropriate questioning, highlighting errors by the prosecution.
Jury instructions asking jurors to assess the situation from Rittenhouse's perspective were significant in the acquittal, legal analysts suggest.
spokespersons: Charles F. Coleman Jr. (Civil rights attorney)
Thomas Binger (Kenosha County Assistant District Attorney)
